is it ok to ask for referrral from developers on linkedin

Yes, it is absolutely acceptable to ask for a referral from developers on LinkedIn. Networking and reaching out to professionals in your field is a common practice, and referrals can be a valuable way to gain visibility and opportunities in the job market. When asking for a referral, make sure to personalize your message, explain why you are interested in a particular role or company, and highlight any relevant skills or experiences that make you a strong candidate. Additionally, be polite and respectful of the other person's time and availability. Building relationships and seeking referrals on LinkedIn can significantly increase your chances of finding suitable job opportunities.

🌟 About Me 🌟

Greetings! I'm Saloni Chauhan, a results-driven full stack developer based in Chicago, IL. With over 5 years of experience, I specialize in crafting robust web applications and providing innovative solutions. Proficient in HTML/CSS, JavaScript, Python, Node.js, Angular, and SQL, I excel in creating responsive interfaces using React/Angular and Typescript/JavaScript frameworks. My expertise extends to efficient back-end development, leveraging technologies like Node.js and Python, and employing MySQL and MongoDB for scalable data modeling. I'm also well-versed in utilizing AWS (Amazon Web Services) for serverless capabilities through AWS Lambda, Amazon S3, and AWS CloudWatch.

Throughout my career, I have collaborated with technical teams, delivering impactful results. Notably, I achieved a 75% load time optimization for multiple dashboards by employing reusable UI components, on-demand loading, and REST APIs. Additionally, I implemented Micro Services in a service-oriented architecture, ensuring RESTful API adherence and clean services for three applications. I have also successfully transformed PHP into a scalable Node/Angular + Python lambda workflow, resulting in enhanced performance and doubled capacity.

My communication skills and commitment to high-quality code consistently contribute to project success within timelines and budgets. I'm dedicated to continuous skills enhancement and staying updated with industry trends.

In addition to my professional accomplishments, I hold a Masters in Computer and Information Security from New England College and a Masters in Computer Science from the Illinois Institute of Technology. I also completed my Bachelor's in Information Technology from Nagpur University.

Feel free to reach out to me via email or LinkedIn to explore potential opportunities. Let's connect and contribute to the growth of the tech industry together!

Subject: Follow-up and Resume Submission

Dear [Recruiter's Name],

I hope this email finds you well. I had the pleasure of speaking with you on Friday regarding the [Job Position] opportunity at [Company]. I wanted to take this opportunity to express my continued interest in the role and to share my updated resume for your review.

I believe our conversation provided valuable insights into my skills and experience, and I am confident that my background aligns well with the requirements of the position. I have attached my resume to this email, and I kindly request you to consider it as the next step towards progressing in the hiring process.

If there are any specific areas or qualifications you believe should be emphasized or modified on my resume, please let me know. I'm more than willing to make any necessary adjustments to ensure it accurately represents my abilities and experiences.

I appreciate your time and consideration thus far, and I look forward to the opportunity to further discuss my qualifications in an interview. Please don't hesitate to reach out to me should you require any additional information or if there are any updates regarding the next steps in the hiring process.

Thank you for your attention, and I hope to hear from you soon.

Best regards,

[Your Name]
[Contact Information]

is ats bullet or numeric firendly

ATS (Applicant Tracking System) compatibility can vary depending on the specific system being used. However, in general, bullet points are more ATS-friendly than numeric lists. Most ATS software is designed to parse and analyze bullet points more effectively, as they provide clear and concise information in a structured format. Numeric lists, on the other hand, may not be processed as efficiently by ATS systems, potentially leading to formatting issues or information not being properly recognized or categorized. Therefore, using bullet points is generally a safer choice when it comes to ATS compatibility.
